This past December some ppl were getting sick and instead of letting them work from home so as to not infect others who are also being forced to come in, they were told they could take 1 day to WFH but that they had to make that day up in office and no more than 1 day to WFH would be allowed. Looking for other opportunities. If you like being treated like a number, by all means apply. Also, this wouldn’t be a big deal as when I applied I was expected to come to work, however, the company sold my original work location and moved us further East which is farther for me and some others. The departing also treats salaried workers like hourly workers. You have shifts which is bizarre, as we have no customer interaction at all. It’s an about control not the work life balance they like to tout. Best of luck.

If you are looking for a more modern company this company really isn't for you. There are so many companies that are moving to a more modern workplace strategy.

You get to place trades that you wouldn't do at most other places in this industry.
cons: The main thing that I have an issue with about this job is that it is a call center. Employee retention is terrible and Wells Fargo (not your direct management but the higher ups) treat you like a number. Just because you are pleasing clients and making a better experience for everyone including other employees, if you do not meet the ridiculous metric targets you will not be rewarded. If you have an issue that your direct manager cannot solve, it probably will never be solved. It is impossible to escalate your concerns. All they care about is earning a dollar for themselves and mitigating risk for themselves. The words "call center" were no were in the job description when I applied and I didn't realize I was signing up for a call center job until 4 months into the job when I finished licensing and training and they hand me a computer and tell me to take as many phone calls as I can every day. The definitely hide all the negative aspects of the job until you are too far in to justify leaving.

Any detail missed can earn harsh reprimand. Other institutions just have everything in one work flow. It’s embarrassing and it’s been like this for years now.

cons: Other Wells departments have GREAT training - this position does not. Trainers mostly give search "tips" for our knowledge database and basic info. One trainer was incredibly unprofessional (he vanished for 40+ minutes with no notice or explanation other than "sorry I stepped away for a bit" and his personal cell phone was ringing and notifying constantly). You learn most of the role while on call (which is fine, except the learning tools are poor). The search engine for articles (which are also required attachments for every call) is inaccurate with poor sorting (eg: search the name of an application - first 7 results will be unrelated, then an article titled after what you searched shows up half a page later). Very poor communication of any issues and outages. The position is just a call center job. Expect to constantly be hounded about sticking to schedule and receive team wide messages telling everyone to do their job or else. Frequent advice for improving numbers is to not take breaks. If calls are particularly heavy you may be told to delay or skip break OR EVEN LUNCH. If you end up having to work on a holiday, the shift is 6 hours with no break or lunch. We have even been told to sign on to everything 20 minutes ahead of schedule and not report it on our timesheet.

review_title: A dinosaur of the mortgage industry
pros: Overall good benefits with a very good parental leave plan.
cons: Unwilling to be a competitor in the market with the highest interest rates out there. Management has zero ability to make any changes for the better. Our senior manager is actively telling people to find new jobs because it won’t get better. On top of not being a market competitor our internal compliance continues to tighten to a point where we as salespeople can no longer have a by sort of ‘natural’ sounding conversation with clients. For example, we have to ask for permission to speak with a buyer’s agent for every single thing we discuss (loan status, preapproval letter, title contact, etc). Wells Fargo has made it clear that they no longer want to be in the mortgage business. Do not work here.
